thread.title: Early-voting sites should be where the voters are
thread.title_full: Early-voting sites should be where the voters are - The Washington Post

author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Early-voting sites should be where the voters are
text:
Early voters line up outside a polling station in Silver Spring in 2012. (Gary Cameron/Reuters) October 15 at 5:14 PM The Oct.13 Metro article “ Montgomery may revise early-voting switch ” missed the point of the disagreement between the Republican and Democratic perspectives. I agree with the general points made in the article, but the issue is not whether one building is better than another for access to early voting — it is that early voting as prescribed by Maryland law is required to be in locations where the maximum number of registered voters can vote early, whether they live near that location or not. The choice by the Republican majority on the Montgomery County Board of Elections to move early-voting centers from very dense population and business centers to rural and sparsely populated suburban locations violates that requirement.
The two locations being closed include the center with the second-highest number of early voters in Montgomery County and with the highest number of minority early voters, and a center situated in one of the busiest business districts, a location with high-density housing and one of the highest percentages of early voters from other districts.
This is about access to early voting by people, not access to buildings.
Darrell Anderson , Washington Grove
The writer is chairman of the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee. The views expressed here are his own.
